description: Enhanced field descriptions with security context for threat hunting and analysis

common_fields.name: aid
common_fields.description: Agent ID - unique identifier for the endpoint

use_cases: Endpoint correlation across multiple event types
Tracking malicious activity to specific hosts
Identifying compromised systems in lateral movement
threat_hunting_tips: Group by aid to find systems with unusual activity patterns
Join with SensorHeartbeat to identify offline/tampered sensors
Correlate suspicious events across event types using aid

common_fields.name: cid
common_fields.description: Customer ID - unique identifier for the CrowdStrike tenant

threat_hunting_tips: Filter by cid in multi-tenant environments
Track sensor distribution across organizations

common_fields.name: ComputerName
common_fields.description: Hostname of the endpoint

threat_hunting_tips: Look for unusual naming patterns that might indicate test/staging systems
Group by ComputerName to identify heavily targeted hosts
Check for hostname changes that might indicate system reimaging or evasion
limitations: Hostnames can be spoofed or changed
Use aid for reliable system identification

common_fields.name: UserName
common_fields.description: Username associated with the activity

threat_hunting_tips: Filter out system accounts to reduce noise
Look for service accounts performing unusual actions
Identify users accessing systems outside normal working hours
Track privilege escalation patterns
limitations: Usernames can be spoofed in some contexts
Use UserSid for reliable user correlation

common_fields.name: UserSid
common_fields.description: Windows Security Identifier (SID) for the user

use_cases: Reliable user correlation (SIDs cannot be easily spoofed)
Tracking user activity across name changes
threat_hunting_tips: Use UserSid instead of UserName for accurate user tracking
Look for SIDs ending in -500 (built-in Administrator)
Track SIDs with RID >= 1000 (user accounts)
Identify service accounts by SID patterns

common_fields.name: ImageFileName
common_fields.description: Full path to the process executable

threat_hunting_tips: Look for executables running from user temp directories
Identify processes with randomized filenames
Check for known LOLBins (powershell.exe, cmd.exe, wmic.exe, etc.)
Find executables masquerading as legitimate Windows binaries
Track execution from web browser cache directories
suspicious_patterns: System binaries (cmd.exe, powershell.exe) in non-standard paths

common_fields.name: FileName
common_fields.description: Base filename of the executable (without path)

threat_hunting_tips: Count occurrences to find rare/unusual executables
Look for typosquatting (scvhost.exe vs svchost.exe)
Identify executables with suspicious extensions
Track specific malware families by known filenames

common_fields.name: CommandLine
common_fields.description: Full command line arguments passed to the process

threat_hunting_tips: Look for base64 encoded commands (-enc, -encodedcommand)
Find credential dumping tools (mimikatz, lsass, etc.)
Identify remote execution (psexec, wmic /node:, etc.)
Track PowerShell download cradles (IEX, Invoke-WebRequest)
Find unusual file transfers (certutil, bitsadmin)
Detect living-off-the-land techniques

common_fields.name: TargetProcessId
common_fields.description: Falcon's unique process identifier (UPID) for correlation

threat_hunting_tips: Join ProcessRollup2 with NetworkConnectIP4 to find processes with network activity
Correlate with DnsRequest to track DNS queries by specific processes
Build process family trees to understand attack progression
Track suspicious child processes spawned from common applications

common_fields.name: ParentProcessId
common_fields.description: Falcon process identifier of the parent process

threat_hunting_tips: Look for uncommon parent-child relationships (e.g., Word spawning PowerShell)
Find processes with no parent (orphaned/injected)
Track legitimate processes spawning suspicious children
Identify suspicious processes masquerading with legitimate parents
suspicious_patterns: explorer.exe as parent for system utilities

common_fields.name: ParentBaseFileName
common_fields.description: Base filename of the parent process

threat_hunting_tips: Look for scripting engines spawned by Office apps
Find system utilities spawned by user applications
Identify browsers spawning unusual processes
Track service processes as parents

common_fields.name: SHA256HashData
common_fields.description: SHA256 hash of the process executable

use_cases: IOC matching and threat intelligence correlation
threat_hunting_tips: Compare against known malicious hashes (VirusTotal, MISP, etc.)
Group by hash to find file prevalence across environment
Track hash changes that might indicate polymorphic malware
Use for exact match IOC hunting

common_fields.name: MD5HashData
common_fields.description: MD5 hash of the process executable

threat_hunting_tips: Use for legacy IOC feeds that still use MD5
Prefer SHA256 for new threat intelligence
MD5 is susceptible to collisions, use with caution
limitations: MD5 is cryptographically broken and can have collisions
Prefer SHA256 for reliable file identification

common_fields.name: SignInfoFlags
common_fields.description: Bitmask indicating code signature validation results

threat_hunting_tips: Look for unsigned executables from unusual locations
Find expired or revoked certificates
Identify self-signed code
Track certificate validity changes
common_patterns: Extract signature flags using bitfield operations
Filter for unsigned binaries in sensitive directories

common_fields.name: ZoneIdentifier
common_fields.description: Mark of the Web (MOTW) zone identifier

threat_hunting_tips: Track executables downloaded from the internet
Identify files from untrusted zones
Monitor email attachments that execute
Find files bypassing download warnings

common_fields.name: RemoteAddressIP4
common_fields.description: IPv4 address of remote connection endpoint

threat_hunting_tips: Use ipLocation() for geographic enrichment
Use cidr() to filter private vs public IPs
Look for connections to unusual countries/ASNs
Track connections to known malicious IPs
Identify beaconing behavior to external IPs

common_fields.name: RemotePort
common_fields.description: TCP/UDP port of remote connection endpoint

threat_hunting_tips: Look for non-standard ports for common protocols
Find high-numbered ephemeral ports used for C2
Track SMB (445) for lateral movement
Monitor RDP (3389) for remote access
Identify reverse shells on common ports (4444, 8080, etc.)

common_fields.name: LogonType
common_fields.description: Windows logon type identifier

threat_hunting_tips: Look for Type 10 (RDP) from unusual sources
Track Type 3 (Network) for lateral movement
Monitor Type 9 (RunAs) for privilege escalation
Find Type 4 (Batch) for persistence via scheduled tasks

common_fields.name: event_platform
common_fields.description: Operating system platform

threat_hunting_tips: Use for platform-specific queries
Track threats across different OS platforms
Identify OS-specific attack techniques

common_fields.name: ContextTimeStamp
common_fields.description: Event timestamp in epoch milliseconds

threat_hunting_tips: Use bucket() for time-based aggregation
Calculate time deltas between related events
Look for activity outside business hours
Find rapid sequences of events (automated attacks)

recommended_filters: Apply time ranges to limit data volume
Use specific aid values when investigating known systems
avoid: Unbounded wildcards on CommandLine without other filters
groupBy() on high-cardinality fields without limits
Regex on large text fields without pre-filtering
